Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC Planning Grant: Next Generation Photovoltaics - Texas A&M University Site
Award.AbstractNarration:
The planned Texas A&M University site of the Next-Generation Photovoltaics (NGPV) I/UCRC will seek to address the major challenge facing the solar industry which is no longer the cost of the cell, but rather the cost of the rest of the "system" that is needed to interface the cells, which generate low-voltage direct current, to the electric utility grid, which operates with high-voltage alternating current. The proposed research site will integrate Texas A&M faculty with expertise in power electronics, materials, grid infrastructure and design, public policy and safety with industry stakeholders in complimentary energy sectors to transform PV into a safe, affordable, and reliable source of electricity. Collaboration among university and industry experts from solar cells to grid promises to enhance the PV market space through significant advances in knowledge and widespread adoption of PV energy.

Efficient, low-cost, and dependable electricity generated from photovoltaics can be this century's electrification project and will lift the standard of living and quality of life in the developing world. The capability and knowledge generated by the NGPV Center can support PV as an export industry for the US - not through manufacturing components, but instead by providing energy solutions. The proposed research site at Texas A&M will leverage public interest in renewable energy to attract students into the field of energy and power electronics. Dissemination and education plans include: scientific collaboration through conference participation, undergraduate and graduate student research, creation of a teaching module and curriculum, and community activities such as "Solar Saturday" to showcase the existing campus 30kW PV demonstration system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Texas A&M University Engineering Experiment Station held the planning workshop for the proposed Balance of Systems research site addition to the existing I/UCRC Next Generation Photovoltaics I/UCRC on June 23 through 24, 2015. The purpose of this workshop was to propose a research agenda to the solar industry and solicit feedback to scope the focus of the proposed I/UCRC research center. The 1.5 day workshop was attended by 45 people representing various aspects of the balance of systems industry ranging from equipment manufactures to installers to k-6 educators. The proposed site’s objective is to collaborate with industry and lower the cost of PV systems, from installation through full operation. The ultimate outcome will transform the role of PV in our energy portfolio into a sustainable and dependable energy mainstay. Texas A&M University’s expertise in the balance of system portion of photovoltaic systems represents a new and synergistic addition to the current NGPV Center’s focus on material science and PV cells. Advances in solar cell technology and economies of scale have substantially reduced the cost of solar cells from $76 per watt in 1977, to $10 per watt through the 1990s, and to under $.70 per watt in 2013. Yet, the installed cost of solar remains beyond the reach of most Americans. The primary cost drivers that remain today, at least in the US market, are labor costs to install and “soft costs” to evaluate, design, permit, inspect, and commission the PV systems.

The primary outcome of the workshop was a clearly defined research agenda that was supported by the industry and which provided the basis of the research proposed in an I/UCRC proposal submitted to the NSF in January 2016.

Intellectual Merit: If solar cells were free, PV energy would still be too expensive to become a ubiquitous form of electrical power. The scope of this problem cannot be addressed by a single individual or entity in the PV market space. The biggest challenge facing the solar industry is no longer the cost of the cell, but rather the cost of the rest of the “system” that is needed to interface the cells, which generate low-voltage direct current, to the electric utility grid, which operates with high-voltage alternating current. Technology alone will not transform the solar industry; it must be accompanied by system level engineering and policy design. The proposed research site will integrate Texas A&M faculty with expertise in power electronics, materials, grid infrastructure and design, public policy and safety with industry stakeholders in complimentary energy sectors to transform PV into a safe, affordable, and reliable source of electricity. Collaboration among university and industry experts from solar cells to grid will enhance the PV market space through significant advances in knowledge and widespread adoption of PV energy.

Broader Impacts: The societal benefit of photovoltaic-based electricity goes beyond reducing greenhouse gas emissions from hydrocarbon combustion. The National Academy of Engineers recognized electrification as the greatest achievement of the last century, not for the sake of the technology development but rather for how it lifted the standard of living. Sunlight is the most widely available form of energy; it doesn’t depend on expensive and complex infrastructure and it can be harnessed at the point of use. Thus, efficient, low-cost, and dependable electricity generated from PV will be this century’s electrification project and will lift the standard of living and quality of life in the developing world. The capability and knowledge generated by the center will support PV as an export industry for the US – not through manufacturing components, but instead by providing energy solutions.
